newsitem.title: UK: Malaysia's Proton buys British car legend Lotus.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia's Proton buys British car legend Lotus.

text.p: Malaysia's ambitious Proton car company and its powerful chairman Yahaya Ahmad took a bold step on to the world automotive stage on Wednesday by buying control of Lotus, the troubled British sports car company.
For an investment of 51 million pounds ($82.7 million), partly from Proton and partly from Yahaya himself, the Asian group secured an 80 percent stake in the specialist firm.
It pledged to apply Lotus's well-known technical and product design skills immediately and to start manufacturing its latest sports car, the lightweight Elise, in Malaysia soon.

At a news conference at the Lotus home base in a converted manor house near Norwich, eastern England, Yahaya and the company's outgoing owner and chairman -- Italian entrepreneur Romano Artioli -- explained they had wanted a deal that kept Lotus intact.
"Lotus is a legend -- it's a name that conjures excitement all over the world. It gives Proton an instant capacity to have products in showrooms that have the Lotus image," Yahaya said.
Artioli said he was glad to have finally found a partner to secure the future of the group's three main businesses -- sports car making, engineering consultancy and motor racing.
"I think I have done my part to ensure that Lotus can now expand its activities," the Italian entrepreneur told reporters.

The deal ends months of uncertainty for the British firm, when Artioli has struggled to find a big investor to restore its financial muscle, and should help distance Lotus from Artioli's failed attempt to revive the classic Bugatti marque in Italy.
Proton planned an immediate increase in British production of the newly-launched Lotus roadster, the $32,500 Elise, and would then add production capacity in Malaysia, Yahaya said.

"With our contribution we can expand Lotus production here...we will expand capacity immediately," he said, adding that he could forsee about half of future Elise production of some 5,000 cars per year coming from Proton plants.
Although by far the bigger company, Proton is an industry newcomer and has an immediate need for product and project advice from consultancy arm Lotus Engineering, Yahaya added.

He stressed, however, that Proton would only call on 15 to 20 percent of the capacity of these specialists and wanted to preserve the engineering team's independence so it could keep working for a wide client base of international manufacturers.

Started by motor racing engineer Colin Chapman in 1948, Lotus was once a leading name in Grand Prix racing, winning world championships with drivers Graham Hill, Jim Clark, Jochen Rindt, Emerson Fittipaldi and Mario Andretti.
Though it has consistently made agile and beautiful cars in small numbers, it also has a long history of turbulent finances.
In 1986 it was taken over by General Motors but piled up losses of 50 million pounds in the five years before its sale in 1993 to Artioli's Bugatti International.

Yahaya, dubbed Malaysia's car czar for his wide-ranging interests in the domestic automotive industry, is the controlling shareholder of Proton. He also chairs its parent industrial conglomerate DRB-HICOM.
Under the terms of the deal he will take a 16.25 percent personal stake in Lotus alongside Proton's 63.75 percent. Artioli will remain on the board, but not as chairman.
Industry analysts in Malaysia lauded Yahaya's latest move.

"It's a very strategic buy. The deal is very positive for Proton in terms of technology transfer and bringing Proton into the luxury sports car sector," said Patrick Lim, automotive analyst at Jupiter Securities in Kuala Lumpur.
The deal should also bring Proton the advanced engine technology it has long sought, analysts added.
Lotus has just finished development of a new engine, its first in 24 years, which powers its large Esprit sports coupe. It intends to offer it to other manufacturers in various forms.
